awd_titl_txt: The First Conference on Machine Learning in Heliophysics; Amsterdam, Netherlands; September 16-20, 2019
awd_abstract_narration:
This 1-year project is to enable the participation of graduate students and early-career researchers at the first conference on Machine Learning in Heliophysics, which will be held in Amsterdam, Netherlands, during September 16-20, 2019.  This international conference is entirely focused on the use of machine learning and information processing tools and techniques in heliophysics, thus encompassing the fields of solar physics, Sun-Earth relationships, magnetospheric and ionospheric physics.  The goal of this first-of-its-kind conference is to improve present understanding of heliophysics phenomena and their dynamics, as well as our ability to predict space weather events by leveraging advancements happening at a fast pace in the machine learning and related communities.  The practical objective of the conference is two-fold: (i) inform the international community on recent advancements in the use of machine learning and related tools and techniques in heliophysics; and, (ii) connect the physics and the computer science communities on the overlapping and multi-disciplinary topic of machine learning.  The research and EPO agenda of this 1-year project supports the Strategic Goals of the AGS Division in discovery, learning, diversity, and interdisciplinary research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The objective of the funded project was to provide partial support for students and early career scientists to participate in the first conference on Machine Learning in Heliophysics which tool place in Amsterdam, Netherlands in  September 2019, and the subsequent conferences on the same topic which were originally intended to take place approximately each year. However, due to COVID complications, in addition to the original meeting in Amsterdam only one more meeting took place in Boulder, Colorado in March 2022.

The intelectual merit of the support provided through this project was the advent of a new discipline, namely the application of machine learning and AI techniques in space physics research. The topics covered included: space weather forecasting, inverse problems, dynamical systems, automatic event identification, feature detection and tracking, surrogate models, and uncertainty Quantification. The methods applied to various areas in heliophysics included: deep learning, system identification, causal inference, combination of physics-based and data-driven modeling, and Bayesian analysis.

The broader impacts were the professional development opportunities provided to students and early career scientists by partially supporting their travel expenses to attend and present their research at these meetings. The conference braught together a cross-disciplinary research community: physicists in solar, heliospheric, magnetospheric, and aeronomy fields as well as computer and data scientists.
